First I'd argue that unicorns are not horses with horns, except in more modern depictions.  Traditionally they are more deer or goat-like, sometimes even depicted with elephants feet. There were no unicorn at all in the Hebrew Bible the word is translated as Oryx https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabische_Oryx/ yes he has two but one sometimes was lost and for the artists it was hard to paint two horns

the original mythos for the unicorn was likely based on the woolly rhinoceros, which was covered in fur and had one horn that was much larger than it's secondary horn. they are depicted in cave art across europe and oral tradition likely would have kept them in the minds of the wandering tribes of the north long after they were gone and, over time, since there were no rhino as reference the would have been compared to other large animals such as deer, goats, and eventually horses as they were introduced to the area, gradually morphing them into the mytholgical creature that we know today.

There are, however, a few unicorn like ungulates in prehistory. Such includes Tsaidamotherium, a muskox relative with one horn much much larger than the other on the top of their heads. It is very unicorn like, albeit perhaps a little more on the cute and fluffy side. Or if you want something more horse like from a taxonomic point, there is Elasmotherium, the elephant sized rhino with a huge single horn not on its nose, but on the top of the head.

I don't know John.... When it comes to unicorns and magical powers, it seems quite likely they would have gone extinct. And, since and number of kind of dishes, potions, tinctures, and other remedies often require all kinds of ground, and powdered parts of animals, flowers, etc, perhaps we were just far too good at making them seem to disappear.
After all, even our foraminiferans buddies that make up the white cliffs of Dover were used in any number of products -- including tooth paste for a while. Then, we've "mummy brown," and the use of people buried no more than several thousand years ago, whose desiccated and preserved bodies were also used for tinctures, and, of course, any number of painting now famous today. People from past times were even more well focused on concepts like, "waste not want not," and "motainai (もたいない)." And, go ahead and watch any number of shows and anime about the past, or play mine-craft, where bone meal does what it does -- grow larger healthier veggies. So, while this is obviously mythology and not anything real, unicorns are not horned horses and I'm a little disappointed that SciShow would participate in spreading easy-to-check bad information. The classical description of a unicorn is closer to an antelope or an oryx (you know, animals with horns). They are slender, with cloven hooves and tails that only got fluffy at the end, like a lion's tail. The whole "horned horse" thing is people getting sloppy and lazy with descriptions.

Guys the term tarantula is 100% wrong because it originally describes european wolfspiders which are a different genus and was just adapted in the english language when the settlers from europe came to the americas. They just kept using it because they didn't know better but nowadays we do. And there is a birdeating spider (<--corrent term for all 'tarantulas' and not to confuse with the Goliath birdeater) with a much longer horn called ceratogyrus attonitifer. This is ceratogyrus darlingi.

That is cool. I knew about the narwal, rhino, rinocerus beetle and rhinocerous hornbill. The narwhal in particular has been agetting more fame and attention. I see stuff in the store with narawals on it. I even have a narawal stuffed animal. A narwhal is a cross beteen a unicorn and a dolphin. So that is two creatures that are very cheerful and popular. So a narwhal is a new spin for a fancy and whimsical creature. I think a horse can benefit from a horn. Stallions sometimes fight for mates. If one of them had a horn, he can stab the other and inflict lots of damage. Then the horned horse can take over a harem more easily. Then he can sire more horned horse babies. Horses have their own spin on the harem structure in that the leader is one of the females, not the male. So if a mare had a horn, it may still benifit. She probably won't be as violent as a stallion. However it may bee easier for her to take over and lead a herd. The whole fighting for mates things is something deer and antelope do with thier horns. So it makes sense for horses to the same. Even rhinos do this, and they hit really close to home. It would be cool if two unicorns charge at eachother and use thier horns to stab. It is the unicorn version of jousting. It would be even cooler if two unicorns used thier horns to fire magical blasts from thier horns. It is more like a wizard dual or Pokemon battle. It can't happen in real life, but that would still be cool.

I have another idea for real life unicorns. This is giraffes. I am very fond of giraffes. I got a lot of giraffe stuffed animals. Giraffes have two knobby horns called ossicones. Male giraffes fight too. They swing thier long necks and hit with the ossicones. Male giraffes are taller than females. I think the benefit is that the extra length of the neck helps the giraffe swing and hit harder. Giraffes have two horns instead of one. This may not seem like a unicorn at first. However there is something else that is. Giraffes have a bloched pattern on thier fur. It can vary. I recently learned that the different kinds of giraffes with different patterns are actually different species. This pattern makes the giraffe look like it has scales, especially from a distance. So Giraffes look like Chinese unicorns, which are called kirin. The kirin of folklore probably came from giraffe sightings.

Actually, according to mythology the unicorn's horn was often included in healing brews. There is a large connection between unicorns and maidens and the mention of unicorns dying of old age is rare. It is my opinion that unicorn horns help to keep it young and healthy. Perhaps unicorns are born without horns because that would be poky for the mama horse, then they are the only ones light enough to reach certain places where the food they eat has the youth-giving compound in excess, which they store into their horns which get larger and larger. However, for safety, they have to sleep with the rest of the herd, away from where they eat. It is safe for them to venture to get food during the day because their predator is diurnal and if they stay munching for too long they get caught and die. Once they reach a certain size they can no longer travel to the feeding grounds of their youth and they start grazing with the rest of the herd. The compound stored in their horns gets absorbed slowly by their bloodstream until old unicorns resemble normal horses. That is partly why we have never found unicorn skeletons or fossils, although unicorn horns can be sourced easily enough for restorative brews.
